item.title: Introducing XBOW
item.description: XBOW brings AI to offensive security. Today we’re announcing the results of testing XBOW on hundreds of web security benchmarks. Without any human intervention, XBOW correctly finds and exploits the vulnerabilities in most of them.

item.title: Breaking Crypto with XBOW
item.description: When I taught Offensive Security at NYU, padding oracles were the hardest attack we covered in our two-week unit on breaking cryptography. So it shocked me when XBOW managed to successfully build an exploit for this vulnerability in one of our novel benchmarks “Bad Captcha”, using it to decrypt a cookie set by the server and bypass its authentication.

item.title: Sequoia Capital leads $20M seed round in XBOW
item.description: XBOW scales offensive security through AI, boosting the work of pentesters, bug hunters and offensive security researchers. It autonomously solves 75% of web app security benchmarks. Sequoia Capital is leading a $20M seed round in XBOW.

item.title: XBOW now matches the capabilities of a top human pentester
item.description: Five professional pentesters were asked to find and exploit the vulnerabilities in 104 realistic web security benchmarks. The most senior of them, with over twenty years of experience, solved 85% during 40 hours, while others scored 59% or less. XBOW also scored 85%, doing so in 28 minutes. This illustrates how XBOW can boost offensive security teams, freeing them to focus on the most interesting and challenging parts of their job.

item.title: XBOW validation benchmarks: show me the numbers!
item.description: XBOW is currently making 104 benchmarks available to the public. This allows other security products, tools, and researchers to use and explore these benchmarks.

item.title: How XBOW found a Scoold authentication bypass
item.description: As we shift our focus from benchmarks to real world applications, we will be sharing some of the most interesting vulnerabilities XBOW has found in real-world, open-source targets. The first of these is an authentication bypass in Scoold, a popular open-source Q&A platform.

item.title: SSRF & URI validation bypass in 2FAuth
item.description: XBOW discovered a Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerability in the OTP preview feature of the open-source project, 2FAuth.

item.title: LabsAI’s EDDI project path traversal
item.description: XBOW discovered a Path Traversal vulnerability in the open-source project, LabsAI’s EDDI.

item.title: Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in 2FAuth
item.description: XBOW discovered a Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the open-source project, 2FAuth.

item.title: The Nightmare Before Christmas: An arbitrary file download on Zoo-Project
item.description: XBOW discovered an arbitrary file download vulnerability on the WPS open source app Zoo-Project.

item.title: Breaking the Shield: How XBOW Discovered Multiple XSS Vulnerabilities in Palo Alto’s GlobalProtect VPN
item.description: XBOW discovered multiple cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities in Palo Alto Networks’ GlobalProtect VPN web application

item.title: Taking the Top Hacker in the US to New Heights: XBOW Raises $75M Series B
item.description: XBOW has reached a critical milestone: our AI now rivals and surpasses top-tier human hackers.

item.title: The road to Top 1: How XBOW did it
item.description: For the first time in bug bounty history, an autonomous penetration tester has reached the top spot on the US leaderboard.

item.title: CVE-2025-49493: XML External Entity (XXE) Injection in Akamai CloudTest
item.description: When XBOW met Akamai: a walkthrough of discovering and exploiting an XML External Entity vulnerability (CVE-2025-49493) in a widely-deployed application.

item.title: Finding XSS in Salesforce Aura Components: How XBOW Got Creative
item.description: How artificial intelligence discovered a widespread XSS vulnerability through methodical testing and creative parameter combinations.

item.title: When the Heat Gets to Your Database: A Refreshing SQL Injection Discovery in Z-Push
item.description:
Summer's scorching heat is particularly brutal this season, making even the most seasoned pentesters dream of cool shade and refreshing drinks.
But sometimes, when you're deep in the trenches of vulnerability research, you stumble upon something that's equally refreshing: a crisp, clean SQL injection vulnerability as good as an ice-cold beverage on a sweltering day.

item.title: XBOW battles Ninja Tables: Who’s the Real Ninja?
item.description: Sharing the story of how XBOW sniffed out a sneaky arbitrary file read bug in the popular WordPress Ninja Tables plugin.

item.title: Agents Built From Alloys
item.description: A simple, powerful innovation boosts performance in agentic AI systems.

item.title: How XBOW turned a JavaScript hint into a working file inclusion
item.description: The XBOW bug bounty effort continues, and this time it uncovered a critical local file inclusion vulnerability by transforming an intriguing SSRF into a full file read exploit.
